PCTR questions

Source: vignettes/articles/pctr-questions.Rmd
pctr-questions.Rmd

The goal of this article is to communicate what I found while characterizing PCTR data and tests.

Here I show code to ask questions that might help us reduce the size of the example data, define the code’s intended behavior, and maybe find bugs and potential improvements. I start with an overview, then explore required columns and rows.

Overview 

library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = TRUE)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tiltIndicator)

packageVersion("tiltIndicator")
#> [1] '0.0.0.9019'

You can find all PCTR data and functions in RStudio with auto-complete.

You can use it all in a single pipe.

out <- pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(pctr_companies)

out
#> # A tibble: 9 × 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… high       0.25      0.5           0.5   
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… medi…      0.25      0.25          0.25  
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… low        0.5       0.25          0.25  
#> 4 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        high       0.6       0.6           0.8   
#> 5 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        medi…      0.2       0.4           0.2   
#> 6 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        low        0.2       0             0     
#> 7 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            high       0.25      0.438         0.688 
#> 8 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            medi…      0.5       0.375         0.25  
#> 9 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            low        0.25      0.188         0.0625

1. Required columns

It’s best to miminize the size of the inputs and outputs, so that the data is easier to understand and easier to work with. Smaller data fits better on screen, uses less disk space, and takes less time to compute on.

Characterization tests show that we may be able to remove columns from both PCTR datasets, and from the output of pctr_score_activities(). Here is the same pipe I showed above but this time with the proposed *_new version of data and code.

out_new <- pctr_ecoinvent_co2_new |>
  pctr_score_activities_new() |>
  pctr_score_companies(pctr_companies_new)

out_new
#> # A tibble: 9 × 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… high       0.25      0.5           0.5   
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… medi…      0.25      0.25          0.25  
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000… low        0.5       0.25          0.25  
#> 4 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        high       0.6       0.6           0.8   
#> 5 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        medi…      0.2       0.4           0.2   
#> 6 ebtor_00000005324899621837001        low        0.2       0             0     
#> 7 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            high       0.25      0.438         0.688 
#> 8 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            medi…      0.5       0.375         0.25  
#> 9 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            low        0.25      0.188         0.0625

Questions:

1.1. Is it OK to remove the proposed columns?

1.2. Is there any additional column we could remove from out_new?

2. Required rows

In addition to removing needless columns, we may also be able to remove needless rows, or restructure the data to make it easier to understand and work with.

pctr_score_activities() has a clear 1 to 1 relationship between the number of rows of the input and output. If it gets 1 row it returns 1 row.

pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  slice(1) |>
  pctr_score_activities()
#> # A tibble: 1 × 15
#>   activity_product_uuid        ei_activity geo   sec   isic_class ref_prod unit 
#>   <chr>                        <chr>       <chr> <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>
#> 1 0a242b09-772a-5edf-8e82-9cb… transport,… RoW   Tran… 4923:Frei… transpo… metr…
#> # ℹ 8 more variables: co2_footprint <dbl>, emissions_unit <chr>,
#> #   perc_all <dbl>, perc_unit <dbl>, perc_unit_sec <dbl>, score_all <chr>,
#> #   score_unit <chr>, score_unit_sec <chr>

pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  slice(1:2) |>
  pctr_score_activities()
#> # A tibble: 2 × 15
#>   activity_product_uuid        ei_activity geo   sec   isic_class ref_prod unit 
#>   <chr>                        <chr>       <chr> <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>
#> 1 0a242b09-772a-5edf-8e82-9cb… transport,… RoW   Tran… 4923:Frei… transpo… metr…
#> 2 be06d25c-73dc-55fb-965b-0f3… treatment … GLO   Wast… 3822:Trea… residue… kg   
#> # ℹ 8 more variables: co2_footprint <dbl>, emissions_unit <chr>,
#> #   perc_all <dbl>, perc_unit <dbl>, perc_unit_sec <dbl>, score_all <chr>,
#> #   score_unit <chr>, score_unit_sec <chr>

pctr_score_copmanies() returns three rows for every input company.

first1_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% unique(company_id)[1])
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first1_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 3 5

first2_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% unique(company_id)[1:2])
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first2_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 6 5

first3_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% unique(company_id)[1:3])
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first3_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 9 5

The number of rows in the output doesn’t depend on the number of rows in the pctr_ecoinvent_co2 dataset.

first1_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% unique(company_id)[1])
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  slice(1) |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first1_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 3 5
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  slice(1:2) |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first1_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 3 5
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  slice(1:10) |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(first1_company) |>
  dim()
#> [1] 3 5

Questions:

2.1. Why is pctr_ecoinvent_co2 25 rows long? 2.2. Can we reduce the size of pctr_ecoinvent_co2 to, say, 5 rows?
